questions.question: Moments later the sun disappeared …………………. the horizon.
questions.description: We prefer below when one thing is not directly under another.

questions.question: We ……………………….. at six while the roads were empty.
questions.description: We do not use begin to talk about starting a journey.

questions.question: You are still …………………………
questions.description: Underneath can only indicate physical position.

questions.question: …………………………. three suspects have been arrested.
questions.description: We can use either all or all the before a number.

questions.question: We spend ………………………… weekends at our country cottage.
It looks ……………………….. it’s going to rain.
questions.description: Like is possible here in an informal style.

questions.question: It is important that she ………………………. told.
questions.description: In British English, should is used before be in this structure. The structure without should is more common in American English.

questions.question: I would like two dozen mangoes ………………………..
questions.description: Altogether can be used to give totals.

questions.question: The committee …………………………. announced its decision.
questions.description: Committee is a collective noun. In American English, collective nouns are always treated as singular.

questions.question: I will telephone you after I ……………………….
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the future tense, we use a present tense in the subordinate clause to refer to future.

questions.question: Martha is a/an ……………………………. woman.
questions.description: Afraid is not usually used before a noun in attributive position.

questions.question: I am going to do my exams, and ………………………. I’m going to study law.
questions.description: After is not used alone as an adverb. Instead we use afterwards.
